subject: Productivity
title: Roman Roads and Standardization
description: A tiny lesson with a big payoff: Roman Roads and Standardization.

hook.text: Rome built 250,000 miles of roads. Some still carry traffic two thousand years later.

buildup.text: Roman engineers standardized road widths, materials, and drainage. Consistency enabled speed.

discovery.text: Standard roads let armies, merchants, and messages move fast. Infrastructure was Rome's productivity edge.

twist.text: The phrase all roads lead to Rome wasn't a metaphor. The road system literally centered on the capital.

climax.text: Rome showed that standardization multiplies output. Repeatable systems beat individual genius.

punchline.text: Standards built an empire. Chaos never could.

quiz.question: How many miles of roads did Rome build?
